titleStmt.title: Happy news to England sent from Oxford. 1. The joyfull hopes of a peace, and of an accomodation that is to be made between the King and his Parliament. 2. The Kings intentions to come to his high Court of Parliament. 3. The preparations that is made for his Majesties comming to White Hall, and the store of provisions of wine and other things that is laid in there for his entertainment. 4. The names of those lords that are nominated to goe to his Majesty with the answer to his late propositions, and to know who his Majesty will nominate and appoint for the accomodation and treaty, and the place where. 5. The security and hostage which is offered by foure noblemen, and also by their estates for the Kings security there and his safe returne to his court at Oxford, if in case the Parliament and his Majesty doth not agree. 6. His Majesties returning to London is suddainely expected, will under God make all those lying astronomers and deceivers, which prophesied of a great battaile prove false and counterfeit.
titleStmt.author: Alsted, Johann Heinrich, 1588-1638.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 9 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 4 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Woodcut illustration of horse and rider (representing Charles I?) verso of last leaf, filmed with with E.89[30] following.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: HAPPY NEWS To England ≈øent from OXFORD.
1. The joyfull hopes of a Peace, and of an Accomodation that is to be made between the King and his Parliament.
2. The Kings intentions to come to his high Court of Parliament.
3. The preparations that is made for his Maje≈øties comming to White Hall, and the ≈øtore of provi≈øions of Wine and other things that is laid in there for his entertainment.

4. The names of tho≈øe Lords that are nominated to goe to his Maje≈øty with the An≈øwer to his late Propo≈øitions, and to know who his Maje≈øty will nominate and appoint for the Accommodation and Treaty, and the place where.

5. The ≈øecurity and Ho≈øtage which is offered by foure Noblemen, and al≈øo by their E≈øtates for the Kings ≈øecurity there and his ≈øafe returne to his Court at Oxford, if in ca≈øe the Parliament and his Maje≈øty doth not agree.
6. His Maje≈øties returning to London is ≈øuddainely expected, will under God make all tho≈øe lying A≈øtronomers and deceivers, which Prophe≈øied of a great Battaile prove fal≈øe and counterfeit.

div.head: Happy Newes to England ≈øent from Oxford.
div.p:
AT this pre≈øent, when in regard of civill warres begun and continued among≈øt us, this Land was the vexed Theame of wretched mi≈øery, and de≈øcrib'd by many pens, and all was ready to become a Wilderne≈ø≈øe of de≈øolation; Peace that divine Grace looking on us with eyes of compas≈øion pittyed our ≈øufferings, and hath lately brought about an unexpected change, and a long look'd for happy event of this bloudy civill warre. The King gracious in his owne di≈øpo≈øition, and alwaies heartily bleeding in the wounds of his Subjects (as him≈øelfe hath often profe≈ø≈øed) hath alwaies laboured by many Declarations for a peace with his Parliament, and now by the advice of grave and learned Coun≈øell, his Royall Heart is enclined to embrace peace, by his Maje≈øty alwaies mo≈øt mercifully defired; ≈øo that now we have ≈øtrong hopes that all divi≈øions ≈øhall bee be compo≈øed by a firme and ≈øetled Union, betweene the Kings Maje≈øty and his high Court of Parliament. This
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ olution accompanied with many other mercifull purpo≈øes, that his Subjects may know him in his owne naturall mildne≈ø≈øe, and this the ≈øeverity of the ≈øword which he formerly u≈øed gave him as many wounds of griefe for his Subjects as it did blowes to others. Let therefore all true-hearted Subjects prepare to entertaine him with hearty affections, ≈øince London ≈øhall ≈øpeedily be ble≈øt with his happy pre≈øence, to bring them both joy and comfort; tho≈øe that with prayers and teares have implor'd Heaven to ≈øee the King againe, ≈øhall now forth-with behold his Royall per≈øon, and with continuall prayers ble≈ø≈øe the houre that brought him back againe to London: for his Maje≈øty is now fully re≈øolved to a≈ø≈øure the Parliament that he is a patient and mercifull King, and that no former pa≈ø≈øages ≈øhall dwell within his memory to ≈øeperate him from them, that he is ≈ølow to wrath, and had rather ≈øuffer than doe his meane≈øt Subjects any injury, and that the ≈øad effects of War, as pillaging, plundering, ran≈øacking of Rich mens Hou≈øes may bee all changed into a ble≈ø≈øed peace. O therefore let our hearts embrace him who doth thus reach out his armes of mercy to receive all his good Subjects into favour. And that it may be more certainly knowne to all his Subjects that his Maje≈øty is purpos'd ≈øpeedily to come to London, and that the de≈øired peace ≈øhall with greater conveniency goe forward, and that it may more forward with greater ≈øpeed, being helped on by his pre≈øence, provi≈øion is made for his comming unto White Hall, that once Sun of Maje≈øty may appeare in this Spheare from whence his beames darted comfortable influence on all his Subjects. His Pallace now of White Hall ≈øhall enjoy his pre≈øence. The Couet formerly turned into a De≈øart, ≈øhall be now againe a Court. Maje≈øty ≈øhall now
≈øit againe enthron'd within the ancient walles of his ancient Pallace, and with the ≈øame life and favour as formerly it did ≈øhall cheri≈øh the hearts of all his loy ‚Ä¢ ll and mo≈øt loving Subjects, and the expected pre≈øence of a King doth create a plenty where≈øoever he comes; ≈øo it being mo≈øt certainely know that the King will come to White Hall, there is preparation already made for his comming; the Genius of the hou≈øe doth already rejoyce, and that mirth may flow in the brea≈øts of all the Court, there is great plenty of rich Wine laid into the Cellars, which doth happily progno≈øticate the Kings comming to his pallace of We≈øtmin≈øter, the inhabitants thereabout doe feele their affections warm'd, with a hope and expectation of getting by the Courts returne, and all London doth li≈øten to this newes as they would to a ≈øacred Oracle of propheticke happine≈ø≈øe; and tho≈øe that doe not wi≈øh his Maje≈øties ≈øociety and a happy peace, let them ≈øhip them≈øelves for new England, or for ≈øome other I≈øland. The pre≈øence of a King long ab≈øent, and tran≈øported from them doth make all Subjects throw of all cares, all fearfull jelou≈øies, all di≈øtru≈øts, and all narrow feares, and enlarge their minde to know nothing but joy, nor ≈øpeake nothing but VIves le Roy, God ≈øave the King. For now the King is comming to rejoyce his people, and that hee may confide in their perfect loyalty towards his Maje≈øty, and know that their Effence doth con≈øi≈øt in his ≈øafe and well being; foure Noble men, namely the Earles of Pembrooke, Northumberland, Holland and Salisbury, have for pledges of ≈øecurity offered them≈øelves and their e≈øtates for his Ho≈øtages, that the Kings Royall Per≈øon ≈øhall not onely be received into London with reverend adoration, but be as ≈øafe among≈øt his true-hearted Subjects, as he conceives him≈øelfe to bee
now among≈øt ≈øwords; and if the happy agreement betweene his Maje≈øty and the Parliament ≈øhould by any cro≈ø≈øe fate be concluded, or that they ≈øhould not comply in that happy manner which is expected (and which God forbid) the afore≈øaid Noble men have interpo≈øed them≈øelves, and given Ho≈øtages that the King ≈øhall then rule over all their de≈øignes, and take his Will to bee his guide in all his actions as his plea≈øure leades him; knowing that he is a regular King, de≈øiring nothing but the liberty of his ≈øubjects, the maintaining the Prote≈øtant Religion, and the Priviledges of Parliament, and that all matters being brought to a happy period, hee ≈øhall if hee ≈øo de≈øire (if agreement be not made) be ≈øafely and royally convay'd againe to his Court at Oxford. But if this City once againe enjoy his pre≈øence, and that the King once againe refre≈øh with his pre≈øence the drooping minds of the Parliament, the day will ≈øhine glorious to the hopes of this kingdome, peace and plenty ≈øhall againe ki≈ø≈øe each other, the Church much di≈øturbed by Sects and Schi≈ømes ≈øhall be confirmed in the true Prote≈øtant Religion, joy ≈øhall overflow the bo≈øomes of the common people; the City ≈øhall flouri≈øh againe in Trading, the Country ≈øhall enjoy the plump fruits of Nature, the times long ≈øicke of a Con≈øumption ≈øhall grow ≈øtrong and lu≈øty, Trading ≈øhall make the mechanick ≈øing, and ≈øuch a Jubile of joy ≈øhall ≈øucceed, that all the Land ≈øhall forget ≈øorrow, and with a cleare countenance relate the ≈øtories of our mixt di≈øtre≈ø≈øes.

We ≈øhall heare no more raging Drumms, no bragging Trumpets, but a peace as ≈øoft as the nights re≈øt ≈øhall cover the heads both of King and ≈øubjects. And what a happine≈ø≈øe this is we may conceive by contraries; what pillaging and plundering hath there been? Father again≈øt ≈øon,
bathing their ≈øwords in one anothers bloud, as if cruelty were be≈øt expre≈øt where there ≈øhould bee mo≈øt mercy expre≈øt. What would bee added to the fierce and bloudy battaile at Edge Hill? the≈øe and future events ≈øhall bee prevented by a happy Peace, by the Kings happy comming and complying with Parliament, by that union and knot of love which is look'd to be tyed againe betweene them; and la≈øtly by the confirmation of a happy and de≈øired Peace; for Heaven hath prevented all Petitions, and in≈øpired the Kings Maje≈øties mind with his Fathers Motto,
‚Ä¢ eati Facifici, Ble≈ø≈øed are the Peace-makers: Heaven is Wi≈øe and cannot be deceived, but hath brought about the great worke, to lay ≈øhame and ignominy on tho≈øe that ≈øcore out the doubtfull fortune of the yeare with fal≈øe Predictions; and to confute tho≈øe lying A≈øtronomers that will needes make the Starres guilty of foretelling of a great Battaile to be fought this yeare. God that rules the Stars will bring the King to London, Peace to the Land, and joy and comfort to the whole Common-wealth.
